title-group.article-title: Quality or Price? Evidence from ODA-Financed Public Procurement

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Antonio Estache, PhD, is on the faculty of Université Libre de Bruxelles, European Centre for Advanced Research in Economics and Statistics. His research areas are public economics, contract theory, and regulation.

Atsushi Iimi, PhD, is senior economist of Finance, Economics and Urban Development Department, The World Bank. His research interests are in empirical auction theory, public finance, and development economics related to infrastructure.

author-notes.corresp: Atsushi Iimi, The World Bank, 1818 H Street NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA Email: aiimi@worldbank.org

abstract.p: Infrastructure is essential for economic growth, and public procurement is an important instrument to use limited resources effectively. Among public procurers there remains a strong view that quality should not be compromised, particularly in high-value transactions, such as infrastructure projects. The common practice excludes incompetent applicants from the selection process. An alternative view is that infrastructure procurement can stimulate the economy by loosing qualification standards. The article examines this trade-off between price and quality. Using procurement data from electricity projects in developing countries, it shows that the adoption of substantive quality qualification increases bid prices for technical reasons and deters the bidder entry, which would raise procurement costs further. The auctioneer’s decision to adopt the quality qualification procedure is also found exogenous, meaning that auctioneers would not compromise the quality of projects regardless of the level of competition. This is an important measure to ensure the quality of complex infrastructure works.

body.p: Infrastructure is among the most important forces driving vigorous economic growth. Developing countries often spend around 7–8 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) for infrastructure investment. However, about 1.4 billion people still do not have access to electricity around the world (IEA 2010). Particularly in low-income countries, public resources are limited compared to the massive financial needs for infrastructure. In Africa, half of the needs are estimated to remain unmet (Foster and Briceno-Garmendia 2010).

Public procurement is an important policy instrument to improve efficiency in public spending and use resources effectively. “[T]he best way to find fiscal space for public investment is to eliminate waste and improve technical efficiency in public expenditure” (World Bank 2005). “There are often considerable inefficiencies in the ways that resources are being used, such that existing resource allocations provide little guidance as to the true costs of providing services efficiently” (World Bank 2008b).

It is still a challenging task for developing countries to take advantage of efficiency in public procurement and ensure value for money in infrastructure projects, which are technically complex, financially expensive, and politically sensitive. Particularly given the recent economic downturn, political interest in a trade-off between price and quality in public procurement has been renewed. Some countries, such as Brazil, are increasingly interested in omitting some of the quality standards and pursuing low prices; but others persist in their efforts to avoid purchasing low-quality goods and services, because infrastructure assets last over thirty years (Lecocq and Shalizi 2009).

The current article casts light on this trade-off between price and quality and estimates the effects of setting quality standards on the bidding behavior, using procurement data from large-scale infrastructure projects. The article briefly discusses a theoretical model to examine the effects of setting quality standards but is largely devoted to an empirical exercise to quantify the value of quality assurance in infrastructure projects. The value can be measured by the additional costs caused by the quality standards required. The article also focuses on examining the endogeneity issues of setting the quality assurance mechanism and the bidder participation in public tenders. These issues will provide important policy implications.

In theory, “quality”—which is referred to as anything that the auctioneer cares about other than prices, such as social and environmental issues—is an important factor to consider in competitive bidding for complex objects, such as infrastructure projects, national defense systems, and perhaps television programs (Cabizza and De Fraja 1998). Multidimensional auction theory suggests that the optimal mechanism maximizing the auctioneer’s expected profits can be implemented by a two-stage first or second quality scoring approach (Che 1993; Branco 1997). If firm costs are not affiliated, the sequence of the price competition and the quality qualification makes no difference (Cripps and Ireland 1994).

The current public procurement practices in infrastructure projects appear somewhat different from the theoretical suggestion. The common procurement practice aims at first excluding incompetent applicants from the selection process. For instance, under the prequalification process, only bidders who meet basic financial, technical, and experiential criteria are allowed to bid. In the two-envelope procedure, potential bidders are requested to submit both a bid price and a technical proposal, and the auctioneer opens the price bid only if the technical proposal meet required standards.

Among public procurers, there remains a strong view that quality should not be compromised, particularly in high-value transactions, such as infrastructure projects. This is because contracting with incompetent and faithless contractors will turn out extremely costly. In Madagascar, for instance, three road contracts amounting to $62 million were terminated, because of the unacceptably low quality of the contractor’s work. The rebidding inflated the contract price by 37 percent due to increased input prices, such as fuel and cement. The projects also delayed for at least two years (Alexeeva, Padam, and Queiroz 2008). In some cases, contracting with unqualified contractors results in enormous costs in casualties. In Vietnam, a large bridge over a distributary of the Mekong River, the Can Tho Bridge, collapsed during construction in September 2007. This caused not only heavy casualties on the project site but also a significant delay of the project, which turned out significantly costly for the economy.

Project delays and cost overruns are difficult challenges to infrastructure procurement. As per Flyvbjerg, Holm, and Buhl (2004), each year of delay would add on average $4.6 million to a project cost of $100 million in the transport sector. In addition, nine of the ten projects experienced some cost overruns (Flyvbjerg, Holm, and Buhl 2002). Chronic delays and cost overruns undermine efficiency and credibility of the budget formulation and execution. In Africa, one-third of the budget allocated to infrastructure is not executed on time (Briceno-Garmendia, Smits, and Foster 2008).

In contrast to the above traditional argument, a new counterview has recently emerged. Too rigid qualification standards may narrow down business opportunities to local firms, hampering economic growth and adding to the procurement costs over the long run. Infrastructure projects can be used as an effective policy tool to enhance local employment and businesses (United Nations Office of Project Services [UNOPS] 2010). In Latin America, large economies announced $25 billion of additional stimulus packages, mostly in the infrastructure sector, in 2008–2009. This is expected to create 2 million jobs or 7 percent of the unemployed in the region (Schwartz, Andres, and Dragoiu 2009). For the same reason, certain US states have a strong preference for labor-intensive technologies in procuring road maintenance works.
1
By loosing or eliminating the quality standards, more small but specialized firms will be allowed to participate in public tenders.

In addition, multidimensional procurement systems involving complex quality assessments may be administratively costly for procurers and increase the risk of project delays. In developing countries, the capacity of executing agencies remains to be built up. In Nepal, the average period required to award a government-financed road project is about a month. But more than three months are required for World Bank road projects where many administrative processes are necessary to ensure the quality of bids as well as integrity of the competition. In recent years, some Brazilian states have reformed their procurement rules allowing contractor price proposals to be assessed before the technical evaluation of submitted bids is undertaken (i.e., inversão das fases). This aims to reduce the risk of having massive complaints, resolutions, litigations and project delays (Blancas et al. 2011). In fact, the most common reason for complaints in official development assistance (ODA)-financed projects is dissent from the bidder qualification and technical bid evaluation (World Bank 2008a).

Every quality aspect will make the selection process more complicated. There is no single answer to the question of how to incorporate quality aspects into prices. The complexity in bid evaluation procedures will lead to susceptibility to political collusion and corruption. Without strong commitment to the predetermined scoring rule, procurement officials can easily manipulate the scoring system (Che 1993). Auriol (2006) estimates the cost of corruption to be between 4 and 10 percent of world procurement spending. In Africa, one-fourth of GDP are estimated to be lost to corruption every year (Thachuk 2005).

The existing empirical evidence is not always in favor of preferential procurement, which is one of the multidimensional auction mechanisms. Even in a good governance society, politicians are often captured. Swedish municipalities with a substantial number of left-wing councilors are likely to procure cleaning services from other contractors than the lowest price bidder. This favoritism is estimated to increase public procurement costs by 38 percent (Hyytinen, Lundberg, and Toivanen 2006). As per Marion (2007), road procurement costs under bid preferences are 3.8 percent higher in California. Citizens can benefit from local employment but may have to bear the heavier tax burden.

Therefore, there are clearly advantages and disadvantages of the multidimensional procurement system, which is commonly used for infrastructure projects. The validity of the current system depends on the costs and benefits of having quality assurance mechanisms in the procurement system. The current article estimates the value attached to the quality assurance in electricity projects in developing countries. Because of the potential endogeneity, the empirical analysis adopts the three-stage least squares (3SLS) estimator. In addition, the treatment effect, instrumental variables, and two-stage probit least squares (2SPLS) methods are applied under certain conditions.

The remaining article is organized as follows. The section on An Auction model with Endogenous Entry and Quality Requirements summarizes key theoretical predictions based on a staged auction model with endogenous entry and quality setting. The third section provides an overview of public procurement practices for infrastructure projects financed by ODA. Estimation Methods and Data section develops our formal empirical models to estimate the symmetric equilibrium bid function. Estimation Results and Policy Implications section presents the main estimation results and discusses several policy implications and is followed by the Conclusion.

sec.title: An Auction Model with Endogenous Entry and Quality Requirements
sec.p: There are at least three effects of imposing a certain quality criteria on bidders who are determining their bidding and entry strategies. First, high quality is normally costly to deliver; thus, the equilibrium bid will increase. Second, high quality may also be costly to prepare, because it requires special skills and technologies that are limited in the market. Endogenous auction theory tells that increased entry costs will decrease the optimal number of bidders allowed to enter the competition (McAfee and McMillan 1987; Levin and Smith 1994; Menezes and Monteiro 2000). Finally, auctioneers may choose whether to tighten or loosen quality requirements with the above two effects taken into consideration.

To examine how these factors interact with each other, a simple government procurement model is considered under the independent private value paradigm.
2

Several important predictions can be drawn from our model. Some are quite consistent with the existing auction literature, and others are new. Some of the key propositions are as follows:
Proposition 1: Bid prices decline and approach the firms' true costs, as competition increases.
This is the traditional competition effect in auction theory. No bidder reveals his true cost. As the number of bidders increases, bidders are forced to submit more aggressive bids to win a contract. In the empirical auction literature, the competition effect has by and large been confirmed (Kessel 1971; Gupta 2002). However, it is still debatable depending on data.
Proposition 2: Participating bidders offer the minimum quality required.
Under the two-envelope bidding procedure, there is no incentive for firms to offer a higher quality of work than required. Quality will add to the cost of firms. This reminds us of the importance of clearly specifying the quality standards in advance—in practice, in the bidding documents.
Proposition 3: The optimal quality threshold (
ξ ∗
) is strictly positive.
This means that the auctioneer always prefers to set a certain quality threshold. It is broadly consistent with our data, as will be shown. About three-fourths of the electricity projects in our sample adopted some mechanisms to assess the substantive technical responsiveness of bids prior to comparing prices.
Proposition 4: If the auctioneer determines the quality threshold endogenously, the optimal threshold increases with the number of participating bidders.
This prediction results essentially from our setting that both price and quality are desirable to the auctioneer. Intense competition would bring down the equilibrium bid as shown above. Given that, quality tends to become more valuable to the auctioneer.

On the contrary, this proposition does not hold, if the government requires a fixed quality standard regardless of the level of competition. In this case, the model translates into a simple lowest-price auction without quality consideration. Quality is never adjusted, even if the expected procurement costs are significantly high. This is in fact one practical approach to ensure the quality of infrastructure work.
Proposition 5: The optimal number of bidders would decrease with the entry cost.
This is the result as the existing endogenous auction theory (McAfee and McMillan 1987). Larger k will reduce the optimal

Proposition 6: The government’s strong preference for quality (ϕ) pushes up the equilibrium bid but decreases the number of bidders. The net impact on the equilibrium bid will depend on these two effects.
Strong preference for high quality no doubt raises the quality threshold to be set. In addition, the model highlights two competing effects of strong preference for quality. On one hand, the equilibrium bid will increase due to purely physical reasons. High quality costs more. On the other hand, the increased quality standard restrains the bidder participation, which will in turn push up the equilibrium bid, because of the (anti-)competition effect.

sec.title: Overview of Procurement Auctions for ODA-Financed Power Projects
sec.p: “[O]pen competition is the basis for efficient public procurement” (The World Bank’s Guidelines: Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits, 7). The procurement method applied to official development projects is basically international competitive bidding (ICB) under the first-price sealed-bid format, because open competition is expected to improve efficiency and transparency in the public procurement systems.

In reality, however, competition in public procurement is often limited particularly in large-scale infrastructure works (Gupta 2002; Foster 2005).
7
In electricity projects, only two or three multinational enterprises may be able to make an entry to the competitive bidding. Even in road construction or rehabilitation works, which require relatively simple skills and technologies, the number of bidders is low at about five to six (Estache and Iimi 2008). In our sample composed of forty-four electricity-related works financed by international aid donors, the average number of bidders is 4.7 with a median of 4. But the majority attracted only two or three firms (Figure 1 ).

caption.p: Probability distribution of number of bidders in ODA-financed electricity-sector procurement auctions

sec.p:
The general rules of competition, including whether or not to adopt the substantive technical evaluation, are set out in the procurement guidelines. Executing agencies of ODA projects are governments or state-owned enterprises, which are normally required to follow public procurement laws and guidelines to purchase goods and services. The guidelines are fairly strict but have certain flexibility in deciding how to package contracts and how to carry out the qualification procedure.
8
In infrastructure projects, the qualification procedure plays an important role in screening bidders and bids and evaluating their technical responsiveness.

In our sample, twenty-nine of the forty-four public tenders for electricity works involved some mechanisms to assess substantive technical responsiveness prior to comparing prices. Electricity projects are usually technically complicated and financially expensive. Thus, this is a normal procedure. Note that the figure includes the two-envelope procedure and other staged quality assessment mechanisms. In some cases, price bids are opened before the technical evaluation is implemented.
9
But no price bids will be taken into consideration, if bidders are disqualified due to technical reasons.

sec.p: Official aid donors are increasingly paying attention to inefficiency in public procurement systems of recipient countries. This is because a significant amount of public resources might be misused and wasted in public procurement (World Bank 2008a). One concern is about limited competition. Another is about ex post contract renegotiation. Contracting with faithless contractors will result in various ex post contract amendments, which would turn out costly. Contracted-out works may not be delivered on time. The costs may overrun the original agreement. The primary objective of requiring technical prerequisites, such as financial background, past experiences, and managerial resources, is to ensure that contractors are competent and reputable and value for money of projects would be maintained during and after the project implementation period.

But every aspect of “quality” may make the procurement mechanism complicated. Staged bid evaluation systems, such as two-envelope process, help procurers to screen potential bidders. In theory, they are implementable (Che 1993; Cripps and Ireland 1994). In practice, the staged bid evaluation contributes to fostering a solid competitive marketplace, because well-qualified firms can price their bids with the knowledge that they are competing against only adequately qualified bidders with minimum competence. In addition, through the staged process, prospective bidders, who may be insufficiently qualified on their own, can avoid the expense of bidding, or attempt to form a joint venture that may give a better chance of success (Asian Development Bank [ADB] 2006).

A crucial shortcoming of the staged bid evaluation is that the process tends to be less transparent and more vulnerable to corruption; authorities can easily exploit excessive discretion (Shaw, Gwilliam, and Thompson 1996; Klein 1998; Estache et al. 2009). Overspecification is a typical indication of corruption and lobbying (Ware et al. 2007).
11

sec.title: Estimation Methods and Data
sec.p:
To deal with the potential endogeneity problem, a system of three simultaneous reduced form equations is considered.
12
The framework basically follows our theoretical model: the equilibrium bid strategy, bidders' entry decision and the establishment of quality thresholds are interrelated with each other. First, the symmetric equilibrium bid, denoted by BID, is assumed to be a function of project characteristics (X), the presence of substantive technical evaluation (DTE) and the number of realized bidders (NUM): 3

This follows the traditional empirical auction literature (Porter and Zona 1993; Gupta 2002; Iimi 2006). The dependent variable BID includes both winning and losing bids, which are considered equally informative in the first-price sealed-bid format. Notably, the number of bidders is specified in the logarithmic form, because it is known that the mapping between winning bids and the number of bidders is never linear (Rezende 2005). The logarithmic models can capture the decreasing marginal effect of competition, which is often observed in empirical auction data.

X is composed of both auction- and bidder-specific variables. For the former, the installed generation capacity in MW (GCAP), total length of transmission lines in km (LINE), maximum transformation capacity of erected substations in kV (SUBS), and estimated engineering costs (COST) are included in the form of the logarithms. Two dummy variables are also included: DDAM for dam construction, which normally requires an additional large cost, and DCIVL for civil works in opposition to equipment supply, which represents the labor intensity of each work.

To control country-specific unobservables, a set of project country dummy variables are included. A number of bidder nationality dummies are also incorporated to control for heterogeneity among bidders. In ICB, bidder nationality is among the most important bidder characteristics. In our sample, for instance, there is a systematic difference in the normalized bids between local and foreign contractors (Figure 4 ). While local enterprises may have comparative advantage in labor costs, multinational companies usually have more experiences of similar development projects and are familiar with advanced technology. Particularly in the electricity sector, foreign companies may have the clear advantage because of their technological skills and competence.

The auctioneer is assumed to decide whether to adopt the substantive technical evaluation process, depending on technical specifications of each project (X) and other exogenous variables Z. The decision will also depend on the level of competition.

For instruments Z, we use three governance indices from the Worldwide Governance Research Indicators database: government effectiveness (GOVE), rule of law (RULE) and control of corruption (CORR).
13
As argued by Hyytinen, Lundberg, and Toivanen (2006), governance would likely matter to the decision on DTE. The database originally covers six dimensions of governance, but we have chosen three of them, because they are of particular relevance to public procurement. Our hypothesis is that the complex technical evaluation procedure could and should be adopted only if government officials are competent and the public procurement system is sound enough. If procurement authorities are corrupt, the technical evaluation may be abused and vulnerable to anticompetitive practices.

The number of bidders is assumed dependent on project-specific characteristics X and an additional set of exogenous variables W, which represent the extent to which potential contractors are willing to apply for a new public work. In addition to Z, three variables are used, which represent potential backlogs that prospective contractors already have. The firm-level backlog is calculated based on the contract amount awarded and the estimated project schedule in our sample market (BKLG). On the country level, the amount of gross ODA disbursement in the energy sector in the three-year period prior to each tender (CAID) is also used for W. Finally, the total disbursement of energy-sector ODA over the developing world (WAID) is also constructed in the same way.
14

The idea behind these instruments is that if prospective contractors are already undertaking a number of similar infrastructure projects, they might be too busy to apply for new public works (Porter and Zona 1993; Jofre-Bonet and Pesendorfer 2000; Price 2008; Bajari, McMillan, and Tadelis 2009). When a firm is devoting most of the resources to other existing contracts, the marginal cost of embarking upon an additional work is considered high. Then, the bidder participation will be limited (Proposition 5).

However, there is an alternative interpretation of these backlog variables. A long backlog may imply that contractors have accumulated project experiences and their capability of undertaking similar works is high. If this is the case, these backlog variables would work to increase the bidder participation. In fact, in large infrastructure projects, bidders are often required to have a certain amount of similar experience in the past.

W also contains governance variables: RULE and CORR. Corruption is undoubtedly an entry deterrence factor. A survey of private sector’s perception of public sector procurement reforms in Nigeria indicates that prospective contractors and vendors would not participate in public tenders because of concerns over alleged corruption, favoritism, bribes, and possible delays in payment even if awarded (World Bank 2008a). In addition, firms are hesitant to participate in public tendering if the judicial system is not reliable. This is because no reasonable arbitration can be expected when any contractual problem occurs.

To estimate equations (3) to (5) together, the 3SLS estimation method (Zellner and Theil 1962) is adopted. Since DTE and NUM are potentially endogenous in equation (3), these variables are first instrumented by all the exogenous variables. Then, the estimated parameters and covariance matrix are repeatedly used to estimate the bid equation until the estimates converge. For computational simplicity, the model is assumed to be (log)linear and continuous all over the system, despite the dichotomy of DTE.

Two alternative estimators are used to test the exogeneity of DTE or NUM. Of particular interest is whether the technical evaluation process is adopted exogenously or endogenously. Equations (3) and (4) can be estimated consistently by the treatment effect model, when the adoption of technical evaluation is considered endogenous but the number of bidders is exogenous. DTE is a binary endogenous choice variable in the system. In the opposite case (i.e., exogenous DTE and endogenous NUM), the conventional instrumental variable (IV) estimator is efficient to estimate equations (3) and (5). The Hausman technique can be used to test the exogeneity, compared to the ordinary least squares (OLS) regression.

In addition, other estimation methods are used to check robustness. This is essential in our case, because our sample includes a fairly modest number of observations. When ignoring the potential endogeneity, equations (4) and (5) can be estimated by the probit and zero-truncated negative binomial (ZTNB) models, respectively. DTE is apparently a binary variable. The number of bidders is a nonnegative integer and typical of count data. However, these estimators may be biased due to the endogeneity. To account for the endogeneity between DTE and NUM, the 2SPLS estimator is applied (Maddala 1983).
15
Using the predicted probability of
D T E = 1
and the predicted number of bidders from the 2SPLS regression, the two-stage least squares (2SLS) model can be used to estimate equation (3).
16

The quantile regression is also applied to account for the possible heterogeneity in bidding behavior. While means, thereby the OLS technique, are sensitive to possible outliers, the quantile regression allows to estimate differences in the distribution of entrant bids more accurately (De Silva, Dunnee, and Kosmopoulou 2003; Ohashi 2008). Notably, however, the quantile technique, even if differencing in quantile regression, cannot solve the endogeneity problem (Arias, Hallocke and Sosa-Escudero 2001). Hence, the two-stage quantile regression (2SQR) estimator is calculated in the winning bid regression context. Five quantiles are examined: .10, .25, .50, .75, and .90.

The data are collected from forty-four procurement auctions for twenty-one electricity projects in thirteen countries assisted by the World Bank and a bilateral donor agency, Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) ODA Operations for the period: 2000–2007.
17 –19 About two-thirds of the total auctions adopted the substantive technical evaluation process, such as the two-envelope procedure (Table 2 ). In terms of the size of contracts, the average engineering cost estimate is about 47 million US dollars, but some are valued at less than 1 million US dollars and others exceeded 400 million US dollars.

sec.p: The sample covers a wide range of projects, from power plant construction to distribution network installation or rehabilitation. It can be civil work and/or equipment supply. The average installed generation capacity is 125 MW with a maximum of 1,200 MW. If a contract is irrelevant to generator erection, then the capacity is set at a very small but nonnegative number (to avoid logarithms of zero). The length of transmission and distribution lines is calculated by adding all installed lines, regardless of transmission capacity (kV). The average length is about 50 km but with a wide range from several to 760 km. The capacity of substation transformers also varies widely between 33 kV and 500 kV.

sec.title: Three-Stage Least Squares Bid Estimation
sec.p:
With all the potential endogeneity problems taken into account, a 3SLS estimation is performed (Table 3 ). The estimated bid equation indicates that the competition effect is significant, as expected in theory. The more bidders, the lower equilibrium bids. It is worth reiterating that the model controls the endogeneity issues. Our estimation result shows that the predicted competition effect is found significant to contain the public procurement costs, even if the endogeneity is taken into account. The bid elasticity is estimated at –.72. If one more bidder additionally participates in a public tender, the government could save 18 percent of total infrastructure costs or 9 million US dollars per contract.
20
This would be significant cost savings.

caption.p: Three-Stage Least Squares Estimation of Bids, Entry and Technical Evaluation

fn.p: Note: Standard errors are shown in parentheses. *, **, and *** indicate the 10 percent, 5 percent, and 1 percent significance levels, respectively.
aMultiplied by 1,000 for presentation purposes.

sec.p:
Quality is found costly. The coefficient of DTE is significant and estimated at .48. This is considered the direct cost of high specifications required by the technical evaluation. There is also an indirect effect; high technical thresholds would likely constrain the bidder entry. The estimated entry equation shows that the coefficient of DTE is significantly negative at –.81. This entry deterrence effect can be interpreted to mean that the required high technical standards would raise the entry costs, thereby limiting the bidder participation. The limited competition would translate into a higher procurement cost. The marginal effect on bids is calculated by
− 0.72 × − 0.81 ≈ 0.59
, which is larger than the direct effect. The finding suggests that there is the risk that too tight technical requirements would severely undermine competitive pressure in the market and push up the public procurement costs.

A policy implication is straightforward. It is costly to implement the substantive technical evaluation, because high-quality requirements will not only increase bid prices but also limit the bidder participation. But this also implies that the project quality assurance is essential, because this estimated cost is considered as the price of high quality. The opposite side of the same coin is that if the quality evaluation process was loosened or omitted, more firms would be allowed to participate in public tenders. Then, the procurement costs could be reduced substantially. Therefore, the view that infrastructure procurement can be used to enhance local employment and stimulate the economy seems to be valid to a certain extent. The question is whether the potential benefits from this stimulus approach are greater than the value of high quality (the marginal value is estimated at .48 plus .59).

The effect of the number of bidders on the auctioneer’s decision about the technical evaluation remains unclear in the equation of DTE. Contrary to our theoretical prediction (proposition 4), the coefficient of ln NUM is negative and insignificant. This may validate an alternative view that auctioneers would take the same quality assurance measure, regardless of the level of competition. The necessity of substantial quality assurance procedures may be determined exogenously, possibly by technical complexity of projects. This exogeneity is examined formally in the following subsection.

Other than interactions among competition, technical evaluation and bidder entry, the 3SLS result indicates that larger projects in physical terms are more costly, as expected. A larger power generation plant costs more, and a longer distribution line work is more expensive to erect. In the bidder entry equation, it is found that civil works would attract more applicants. This may be because labor-intensive contracts require relatively lower skills and can be easily undertaken. While a few companies may be able to apply for large power generator installation and commissioning work, a number of construction companies may be able to apply for civil works. For the same reasons, a relatively large number of firms will apply for transmission and distribution line works. It is evident that works in the network segment are labor-intensive and exhibit significant economies of scale. On the other hand, generator-related works needs high technical skills. Thus, more bidders would be likely to participate in the competition for larger transmission and distribution contracts.

Good governance has been found to encourage more contractors to participate in public tenders. The coefficients of RULE and CORR are both significant and positive in the entry equation. Where the reliable rule of law and anticorruption policy are established, the entry cost for firms would be low; thus, competition would be intense. This is consistent with a view in World Bank (2008). The coefficients of BKLG and CAID are found positive, but only the latter is statistically significant. It means that if a country implemented many electricity development projects in the past, a larger number of bidders are expected to apply for new public contracts. This suggests the importance of private business development in connection with public infrastructure procurement.

In terms of the auctioneer’s decision of whether to impose the substantive technical requirement, it is shown that good governance would facilitate the use of the complex technical evaluation procedures. Numerically, the effect of government effectiveness is largest among the selected governance indices. This is encouraging in the sense that the technical evaluation would likely be used by competent authorities, rather than corrupt governments.

There are three particular remarks to interpret the above result. First, our quality measurement is imperfect. It merely captures some of the quality issues of infrastructure projects. The technical evaluation in the bid evaluation process focuses on only technical responsiveness of bids and bidders. Whether the selected project design is technically best is a different question. Second, the analysis ignores the administrative cost of auctioneers. It may be administratively costly for procurers to implement the substantive technical evaluation for highly complex infrastructure projects.

Third, one may be concerned that the adopted instrumental variables are not valid in the current setting. To see the validity, the conventional overidentifying restriction test statistic is calculated. It is estimated at 11.87 and the hypothesis cannot be rejected at the 10 percent significance level. The p-value is .064. Hence, the used instruments appear appropriate to the extent that they are not seriously correlated with the error term in the bid equation, ϵ1. In addition, the instruments are not weak. They have been found to explain the variation in the entry and auction design decisions. The adjusted R 2 values in the first stage regressions of the 3SLS are all greater than .7.

sec.title: Exogeneity Tests for Bidder Participation and Quality Requirement Setting
sec.p: The 2SLS technique allows to apply the Hausman exogeneity test to examine whether the bidder participation is exogenous. The exogeneity of the auctioneer’s setting quality requirements can also be tested. It is worth recalling that these endogeneity issues are a fundamental question in estimating equation (3).

Compared with the simple OLS estimator, the null hypothesis that both NUM and DTE are exogenous in the bid equation cannot be rejected. The chi-square test statistic is negative at –5.02, which can be interpreted as strong evidence that the hypothesis cannot be rejected. Notably, however, there is still a possibility that one of these factors is determined endogenously.

The exogeneity test for the number of bidders under the presumption that the adoption of the technical evaluation is endogenous can be rejected. In this case, the fully efficient model under the null hypothesis is the treatment effect model, because a binary variable, DTE, is the only endogenous regressor in the bid equation (Table 4 ). The test statistic is estimated at 5.58, which is above the 95 percent critical value in the chi-square distribution with one degree of freedom, and the exogeneity hypothesis can be rejected. Therefore, the number of bidders is likely to be endogenous.

caption.p: IV and Treatment Effect Regressions on Bids

fn.p: aSome of the dummy variables are omitted for the first stage probit for the treatment model due to multicollinearity.
Note that the standard errors are shown in parentheses. *, **, and *** indicate the 10 percent, 5 percent, and 1 percent significance levels, respectively.

sec.p: On the other hand, under the presumption that the number of bidders is endogenous, the exogeneity associated with DTE cannot be rejected. The fully efficient model under the null hypothesis is the conventional IV estimator with the number of bidders instrumented. The Hausman test statistic is –8.22. Therefore, it can be concluded that the technical evaluation decision is likely to be exogenous.

Policy implications are clear: the bidders' decision to enter the market is a dynamic and endogenous process. Thus, the degree of competition cannot be measured by the number of bids alone. This is consistent with the philosophy of the standard procurement guidelines used in ODA projects. “Rejection of all bids is justified when there is lack of effective competition,” but “[l]ack of competition shall not be determined solely on the basis of the number of bidders. Even when only one bid is submitted, the bidding process may be considered valid, if . . . prices are reasonable in comparison to market values.”
21

There are a number of measures to influence this process of competition. Centralization of procurement information (such as contracts, prices, and bidders), as in the electronic procurement system in São Paolo, can help consolidate and publish data efficiently (Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development [OECD] 2005). The Construction Sector Transparency (CoST) initiative, an international multiple stakeholder initiative is intended to deepen transparency and accountability in the public construction sector by providing comprehensive and periodical disclosures and publication of information regarding public tenders and works (World Bank 2008). The disclosure of engineering cost estimates is also a powerful tool to prevent corruption and motivate more potential contractors to enter public procurement markets (De Silva, Dunne, and Kosmopoulou 2003; Flambard, Lasserre, and Mohnen 2007).

By contrast, the quality standards are determined exogenously. This is an important measure to ensure the quality of public work. Especially, electricity development projects are normally significant by size and technically complex. Therefore, the substantive technical assessment cannot be compromised by nature of projects, and the data are supportive of this. Recall that government effectiveness was found important to carry out the substantive technical evaluation in Table 3. Hence, technical assistance will have an important role to play in helping procuring agencies to implement the public procurement with proper quality assurance mechanisms.

sec.title: Robustness Check
sec.p: One of the robustness checks has already shown above in Table 4. Besides the endogeneity issues, the estimated treatment effect and IV results are in line with our main results. Particularly in the IV estimation, which is considered consistent if DTE is exogenous as discussed earlier, the coefficient of the number of bidders is estimated at –.73. The variable of DTE has a coefficient of .48. Thus, public procurement costs could be lowered by competition but would be pushed up by setting high technical standards.

The first stage regression of the IV estimation also shows that anticorruption policies and private business development are of particular importance to encourage bidder participation in public tenders. These are also consistent with the 3SLS in Table 3.

When the endogeneity of DTE or NUM is ignored, the probit regression and ZTNB regression can estimate the binary decision of adopting the technical evaluation process and the number of bidders, respectively (Table 5 ). Of particular note, the number of bidders seems to decrease with the amount of backlogs at the firm level; the coefficient of BKLG is negative and significant. However, these may be biased because of the endogeneity.

caption.p: Probit, Negative Binomial, and Two-Stage Probit Least Squares Regressions for Entry and Technical Evaluation

fn.p: Note: Standard errors are shown in parentheses. *, **, and *** indicate the 10 percent, 5 percent, and 1 percent significance levels, respectively.

sec.p:
To control the potential interdependency between them, the 2SPLS regression is employed. Important, the 2SPLS estimator provides the best predicted values of our two endogenous variables, DTE and NUM, in connection with the combinations of all the exogenous variables. The result indicates that auctioneers may be more likely to use such a mechanism as the number of participants increases, though still statistically ambiguous. Government effectiveness is found especially important to rely on the technical evaluation for the public procurement. The coefficient of BKLG is, again, significantly negative, meaning that if firms are already devoted to other electricity development projects elsewhere, fewer bidders could apply for a new public tender and competition would likely be limited.
22

To check robustness of our 3SLS result, the 2SLS technique is also applied and the equilibrium bid function is reestimated. This is an alternative consistent estimator. Not surprisingly, the result is broadly similar. The more competition, the lower public procurement costs. If the substantive technical evaluation process is adopted, the equilibrium bid would increase substantially (Table 6 ).

sec.p: To see possible heterogeneity in the bidding strategy, the 2SPLS result also allows to perform the 2SQR at the different levels of bids (Table 6). The evidence is generally confirmatory to the above results, but the competition effect seems to have a relatively large impact in the lower tail; the coefficient of the predicted number of bidders is –0.99 and –1.19 for the 10th and 25th percentile bids, respectively. In the presence of many opponents, bidders would likely submit aggressive bids on smaller contracts. By contrast, competition might be less effective for large contracts, possibly because they are already highly complex and specific. The direct cost of required technical standards is also relatively high in the lower tail, though the 10th percentile regression has an insignificant coefficient in this regard.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Infrastructure is one of the most important forces driving economic growth. However, public resources are extremely limited compared to the remaining large needs for infrastructure in developing countries. Public procurement is an important policy instrument to use limited public resources to develop infrastructure.

How to take advantage of benefits from public procurement is a difficult question. Among public procurers, there remains a strong view that quality should not be compromised, particularly in high-value transactions, such as infrastructure projects. The common procurement practice first excludes incompetent applicants from the selection process. Indeed, contracting with incompetent and faithless contractors will turn out extremely costly.

In recent years, a counterview has been renewed: infrastructure procurement can be used as an effective policy tool to foster local businesses and stimulate the economy. By loosing qualification standards, more business opportunities cold be opened to local firms, which can help to sustain economic growth. However, there always remains the risk that the quality of works may deteriorate, causing cost overruns, project delays, or even heavy casualties.

The current article casts light on this trade-off between price and quality. By estimating the system of simultaneous equations with procurement data from large electricity projects, it is found that the adoption of substantive technical responsiveness assessments would cost more in two ways. First, higher quality is expensive for purely physical reasons. Second, the introduced technical evaluation would deter the entry of bidders. The limited competition would increase public procurement costs further. In other words, the value attached to the quality assurance in infrastructure projects is undoubtedly high. But at the same time, this means that if the substantive quality evaluation was loosened or dropped, more firms would be allowed to participate in public tenders. Although there remains the risk of cost overruns and project delays, the public procurement costs could be reduced considerably.

Another important finding is that auctioneers would not compromise the quality of projects, regardless of the realized level of competition. It is shown that the decision to adopt the substantive technical evaluation is less likely to be endogenous. This may be an important practice to ensure the quality of infrastructure projects. Governance, especially government effectiveness, is found to be an important factor to allow developing countries to carry out the technical bid evaluation in complex infrastructure projects. Technical assistance to develop sound procurement capacity seems essential.

The labor requirement for a road project of equal value is much higher in the Southeast and South Central states, compared with other states (Anderson and Jacoby 2000). Labor intensity does not necessarily mean that the quality of work is low. However, technical skills and financial background required for a work are clearly low if project specifications are labor-intensive.

It is arguable whether each empirical auction is characterized as the independent private value or common value paradigm. In theory, they may lead to much different bidding patterns (Milgrom and Weber 1982). Especially in the latter setting, competition may increase the equilibrium bid due to the winner’s curse (Paarsch 1992; Klemperer 2002; Hong and Shum 2002; Athias and Nunez 2008). In reality, any empirical auction has both symmetric and asymmetric uncertainties for bidders. However, our belief is that in the ODA-related infrastructure procurement, asymmetric uncertainty among bidders plays a relatively important role in determining the individual bid prices, whence in favor of choosing the independent private value paradigm. Typical are labor costs of individual contractors. Even though the same amount of inputs is required to implement a project, unit costs (e.g., wages and equipment prices) are different across firms (Bajari, McMillan, and Tadelis 2009). Also those private cost factors remain different even after the contract is awarded. By contrast, auction-specific symmetric uncertainty, such as political instability and regulatory credibility, may often matter to the public–private partnership (PPP) infrastructure auctions. However, in traditional ODA projects, the objects to be procured are much specific and the common factors are relatively limited.

The firm’s private cost is also assumed to be multiplicative, rather than additive, with the squared quality requirement. This reflects the nature of the infrastructure procurement market; the firm’s expected profit would increase, when the project quality is strongly emphasized and applicable technologies are scarce in the market. Under this functional form, the variance of the cost distribution increases, as the quality requirement increases. As the variance of costs goes up, the markup of a firm’s bid over its cost also increases, because an expected difference in costs between the firm and its rivals will be enlarged due to the squared term of quality. This effect is even clearer, when the positive entry cost is considered, as in our model.

This implicitly assumes that the public contract is enforceable and verifiable. There is no hidden action problem between the auctioneer and the contractor. The analysis focuses on the information asymmetry about firms' true costs, which is aimed to be solved through competitive bidding. This setup is different from some of the existing literature analyzing the principal-agent problem in the procurement context (Anthon, Bogetoft, and Thorsen 2007)
Otherwise, the auctioneer would require the highest possible quality, no matter what it would cost.
See an earlier version of this article (Estache and Iimi 2009) for further derivation.

According to the Private Participation in Infrastructure (PPI) database, the top 10 percent largest firms—defined by the number of transactions that each company obtained—were awarded about half of total infrastructure PPP contracts.

The World Bank’s Guidelines: Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits stimulate that “[t]he size and scope of individual contracts will depend on the magnitude, nature, and location of the project. For projects requiring a variety of goods and works, separate contracts generally are awarded for the supply and/or installation of different items of equipment and plant,” but “[i]n certain cases the Bank may accept or require a turnkey contract.” Local competitive bidding (LCB) may also be available for ODA-financed projects. The Guidelines may allow borrowers to use LCB if the contract values are so small or works are so labor-intensive that foreign bidders would not be interested.
We do not focus on the prequalification procedure, which is by and large adopted in complex electricity projects.

Needless to say, these figures do not control any other heterogeneity in projects and bidders nor the possible endogeneity bias caused by bidder entry and auction design, which will be accounted for in the following formal empirical analysis.

In the multidimensional auction literature, there has been little consideration of the entry problem. Conversely, in the endogenous entry auction context, the multidimensionality has not been argued, either. In reality, the auctioneer’s decision on whether to adopt some technical evaluation schemes is interdependent on how many bidders can be expected to participate.

An obvious alternative is the structural econometric estimation, such as Paarsch (1992); Guerre, Isabelle, and Quang (2000); and Bajari, McMillan, and Tadelis (2009). However, our limited sample does not allow us to take the structural approach, though our theoretical model provides a structure model. The following analysis takes a reduced form approach in consistency with our model.

Each index is normalized on a scale from –2.5 to 2.5 on a global basis. See Kaufmann, Kraay, and Mastruzzi (2008) for all the specific details. To avoid further complications related to the possible endogeneity of governance, the lagged values are used; each index is defined by the three-year average score before a particular contract is auctioned. Therefore, these indices are country-specific but auction-variant, depending on auction year.
The aid data originate from the OECD Creditor Reporting System database. Both are in constant 2005 US dollar terms.

In the 2SPLS estimator, the two-stage approach is taken where the probit and OLS models are first performed for DTE and ln NUM, respectively. Then, the standard errors are corrected by the estimated individual variance–covariance matrices and a correlation between the two equations.

This two-step probit approach is merely an approximation to the 2SLS (Maddala 1983). However, it is considered good even if the potential correlation between the error terms is high (Nicoletti and Peracchi 2001).
